Modules¶

Introduction¶

For this update, there was a desire to simplify processes, and minimize the proliferation of modules. This means, as long as it makes makes sense, to have one module per functionality. Meaning: one module for deleting, another for adding and so on and so forth. But here I broke this rule with the choice_feeds.py module, It gets and treats all the feeds information. This, in principle, should be aggregated with the show_feeds.py module, but the truth is that there is a lot of user input regarding what feeds are used and when. Also these user choices have to be treated differently, as per the question or the answers. Taking into account the complexity that is involved in this step, it made sense to me that it should have its own module.

Add Feeds¶

Module to add feeds to the application.

rss.add_feed.add_feed(feeds)[source]¶

Function is started with a string with an url or a list of urls. Each url is ran through feedparser to get the feed title. Creates a tuple of the feed title and its url. Adds it to the feedlst.bin file.

Delete Feeds¶

Module to delete feeds from the feed list.

rss.delete_feed.delete_feed(dels)[source]¶

Gets a feed or list of feeds to delete, builds new feedlst.bin file without them.

Update Feeds¶

Module that deletes the database before updating it. We keep only the latest results in storage.

rss.update.delete_entries()[source]¶

Deletes all entries in the database. We only care about the latest content.

DELETE FROM rss
rss.update.upload_feed(answers)[source]¶

Parses all feeds and uploads them to the database. Uses multiprocessing to speed up the process.

INSERT INTO rss (name, title, link, time) VALUES (?1, ?2, ?3; ?4)

Choose Feeds¶

Updates, chooses and collects feed data, asked by the user.

rss.choice_feeds.update_query()[source]¶

Asks the user if he wants to update the database.

Command:

Do you want to update the results?

Command:

python update.py

rss.choice_feeds.choose_feeds()[source]¶

Selects entries in the name column and displays the results. The user can choose, one, many or all.

SELECT DISTINCT name FROM rss
Command:

What feeds do you want to see?

Returns:

feedschoice

rss.choice_feeds.get_feeds()[source]¶

Gets the feed information for the publications chosen in the last function. It has different queries in case its various feeds, one feed, all feeds.

SELECT * FROM rss WHERE name IN <choices> ORDER BY RANDOM
SELECT * FROM rss WHERE name = '{choices[0]}'
SELECT * FROM rss
Returns:

records

Show Feeds¶

Module to decorate the feed data and present it.

class rss.show_feeds.DecorateShowFeeds[source]¶

  1. Imports the data of chosen feeds.

  2. Defines color pallettes to decorate each feed.

  3. Alocates a pallette to a feed.

  4. Shows feeds in terminal.

records()[source]¶

Runs get_feeds module to ask the user what information he wants to see.

As get_feeds uses multiprocessing, it can’t be imported traditioanlly, so we call it, through subprocess, with a python command.

Command:

python get_feeds.py

pallettes()[source]¶

Color pallettes to be atributed randomly to each chosen feed. Creates a list of pallettes that’ll be used in the next method.

name_to_pallette()[source]¶

Creates a list of tuples with a chosen feed name and a pallette.

We want different pallettes for each publication. For this we need to ensure that, everytime that ‘random’ chooses a new pallette, there is only unused pallettes as options. To do this, we pop the used options out of the list of choices. It creates a self.name_pallette list, with tuples with the feed name and the its pallette.

show_feeds()[source]¶

Alocates pallette values to the feed content, using Blessed terminology. Shows the results.

Main Module¶

Main module of rss. Initiates the application.

rss.main.main()[source]¶

Collects user input about:

  1. What functionality to use.

  2. If it’s delete feeds, what feeds to delete?

  3. If it’s add feeds, what urls do you want to add?

  4. If it’s show feeds, what feeds do you want to see?

Command:

What do you want to do?

Command:

What feeds do you want to delete?

Command:

What feeds do you want to add?
